On Thu, 19 Aug 2004 22:05:44 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Yes the parameters are all correct and I agree that it seems counter
> intuitive. Actually I think you answered this question yourself in your
> response to John -  crossover. 

Well, this still doesn't make sense to me.  How are you handling
crossover?  ANJI works as the original NEAT paper described--when two
individuals mate, the topology of the fitter individual is used, while
weight values for common connections have a 50/50 chance of coming
from either parent.

Even if you're handling it another way, it still doesn't seem to make
sense.  Our mutation rates for blended runs for Tic-Tac-Toe were :

add neuron: 0.005
add connection: 0.01
remove connection: 0.02

They were roughly balanced, and as a consquence, the average
complexity for most runs remained steady.

Your subtractive mutation rates were triple your additive ones, so
average complexity should be decreasing each generation.  Does your
method of crossover always take the topology of the more complex
individual or something?

> I truly beleive that this is down to species culling, and the phased
> search graph backs up the idea. SharpNEAT employs elitism at the species
> level, that is, each species' keeps at least it's 1 best genome and in
> the experiments actually kept the best 20%,.

I'm sorry...I still don't understand the explanation.  But if you're
using Ken's basic NEAT implementation and population fitness is
steadily *decreasing* throughout the run, it certainly seems that
something is wrong.

Ken?  Have you looked at the fitness graphs on Colin's page?  Does
this make sense to you?

> Have a look back in the archives, I think species culling was discussed
> some time ago when I poitned out that quite often a jump in fitness can
> be seen shortly after culling the fittest species. 

Yeah, I remember the discussion and thought it made sense at the time
as a way of enhancing the performance of a run.  I don't see how it
should be *degrading* the performance of traditional or blended NEAT.

Derek
